effect.@en: These creatures cannot be harmed by normal weapons, unless they have been imbued with Magick.

Creatures in Æthereal Form cannot inflict Damage or manipulate physical objects, but can pass through objects effortlessly and hover 1 yard off the ground. They can manifest into physical form instantaneously, but assuming Æthereal Form once more costs 2 APs.
Every time these creatures inflict an Injury, they move one step up the Damage Condition Track positively.
Once this creature is Grievously Wounded, it can no longer fly.
When these creatures reduce a foe to Seriously Wounded, the foe’s wounds are Infected. When they reduce a foe to Grievously Wounded, the foe contracts the Disease indicated in parentheses.
These creatures refer to their [AB] for all Damage they inflict with weapons. They also have factored in +3 to their [AB].
These creatures’ movement uses 6+[AB] on foot and 9+[AB] for flight. Fliers are indicated under Movement.

When first encountered, these creatures provoke one of the three brands of Madness; if of Basic Risk Factor, they provoke Stress; if of Intermediate Risk Factor, they provoke Fear; if of Advanced or Elite Risk Factor, they provoke Horror.
These creatures may take any form they please, providing it is of a Small or Large Animal or Humanoid (including player Ancestries).
When these creatures execute a successful attack while flying, they also deal 1D10+[AB]physical Peril.

description.@en: Another weapon favored by the assassin, it’s concealable and designed for quick stabbing thrusts. An intended victim can bleed like a stuck pig if this weapon is thrust in the right way.

In these dark times, even children need to be made aware that they should not place trust in anyone, not even their own family; the reason being they never know who could be a dreaded Lamashtu. The Lamashtu is cowardly, taking flight when it senses danger, but otherwise these Vampires are terrible monsters and mimics, sating their hunger with the blood of babes. Able to polymorph its own shape, they assume the form of an elderly woman and pass into villages unmolested and unnoticed, seeking children to feed upon.

They can even mimic voices, but since Lamashtu are more creature than man, it is little more than parroting vocal noises. The Lamashtu, now fully disguised and holding the child’s trust, escorts the babe out of the village to a remote killing ground. Once there, the Lamashtu reveals its true form: that of a bristling giantess, with a marsupial-like face, gangling limbs and eyes the size of tea saucers. The Lamashtu is most vulnerable in this form, so they only take it on to feed or when cowed.
